etymologies: late Old English (as the name of a water plant mentioned by Pliny), from Latin. The current sense dates from the early 17th century

definitions: an edible seaweed with thin flat fronds of a reddish-purple and green color that becomes black when dry. Laver typically grows on exposed shores, but in Japan it is cultivated in estuaries.
shortDefinitions: edible seaweed with thin flat fronds

etymologies: Middle English: from Old French laveoir, from late Latin lavatorium ‘place for washing’ (see lavatory)

definitions: a basin or similar container used for washing oneself.
shortDefinitions: basin or similar container used for washing oneself

definitions: (in biblical use) a large brass bowl for the ritual ablutions of Jewish priests.
shortDefinitions: (in biblical use) large brass bowl used by Jewish priests for ritual washing
